description: From Middle English suavyte, suavite, suavitee, from Middle French suavité and its etymon Latin suāvitas.

entries.meaning: The quality of being sweet or pleasing to the mind; agreeableness; pleasantness
examples: [...] nothing, not even the crude curves of the railway, can utterly deform the suavity of contour of one bay after another along the whole reach of the Riviera.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Sweetness or agreeableness to the senses, especially of taste and odour.
